DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. In faith, I will, lo; never trust me else.
  DIOMEDES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Give me some token for the surety of it.
  CRESSIDA. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. I'll fetch you one.                                  Exit
  ULYSSES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. You have sworn patience.
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Fear me not, my lord;
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Fear me not, my lord;
    I will not be myself, nor have cognition
    Of what I feel. I am all patience.
  THERSITES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Now the pledge; now, now, now!
  CRESSIDA. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.
  TROILUS.

CRESSIDA

  ULYSSES.

  CRESSIDA.

  DIOMEDES.

  CRESSIDA.

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. It is no matter, now I ha't again.
  THERSITES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Now she sharpens. Well said, whetstone.
  DIOMEDES.

  CRESSIDA.

  DIOMEDES.

  DIOMEDES.

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. I had your heart before; this follows it.
  TROILUS.

  CRESSIDA.

TROILUS

CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not;
  DIOMEDES.

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. I will have this. Whose was it?
  CRESSIDA.

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. It is no matter.
  DIOMEDES.

PRIAM

ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Come, tell me whose it was.
  CRESSIDA. 
12

PANDARUS

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. 'Twas one's that lov'd me better than you will.
  DIOMEDES.

  DIOMEDES.

  TROILUS. 
12

PANDARUS

DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Wert thou the devil and wor'st it on thy horn,
  CRESSIDA. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past; and yet it is not;
  DIOMEDES. 
12

ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Why, then farewell;
  CRESSIDA. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. You shall not go. One cannot speak a word
  DIOMEDES. 
12

ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. I do not like this fooling.
  THERSITES. 
12

ULYSSES
PARIS

PRIAM

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Nor I, by Pluto; but that that likes not you
  DIOMEDES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. What, shall I come? The hour-
  CRESSIDA. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Ay, come-O Jove! Do come. I shall be plagu'd.
  DIOMEDES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Farewell till then.
  CRESSIDA. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Good night. I prithee come.                 Exit DIOMEDES
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. A proof of strength she could not publish more,
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. All's done, my lord.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. It is.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Why stay we, then?
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. To make a recordation to my soul
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. I cannot conjure, Troyan.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. She was not, sure.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Most sure she was.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Nor mine, my lord. Cressid was here but now.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Let it not be believ'd for womanhood.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. What hath she done, Prince, that can soil our mothers?
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Nothing at all, unless that this were she.
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Will 'a swagger himself out on's own eyes?
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. This she? No; this is Diomed's Cressida.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. May worthy Troilus be half-attach'd
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. He'll tickle it for his concupy.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false!
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. O, contain yourself;
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. O, contain yourself;
    Your passion draws ears hither.
  AENEAS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. I have been seeking you this hour, my lord.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Have with you, Prince. My courteous lord, adieu.
  ULYSSES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. I'll bring you to the gates.
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Accept distracted thanks.
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Accept distracted thanks.
            Exeunt TROILUS, AENEAS. and ULYSSES
  THERSITES. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would croak like
  THERSITES. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would croak like
    a raven; I would bode, I would bode. Patroclus will give me
    anything for the intelligence of this whore; the parrot will not
    do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab. Lechery,
    lechery! Still wars and lechery! Nothing else holds fashion. A
    burning devil take them!                                     Exit
  ANDROMACHE. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
DROMACHE. When was my lord so much ungently temper'd
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. You train me to offend you; get you in.
  ANDROMACHE. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
DROMACHE. My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. No more, I say.
  CASSANDRA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. Where is my brother Hector?
  ANDROMACHE. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
DROMACHE. Here, sister, arm'd, and bloody in intent.
  CASSANDRA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. O, 'tis true!
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. Ho! bid my trumpet sound.
  CASSANDRA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother!
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. Be gone, I say. The gods have heard me swear.
  CASSANDRA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows;
  ANDROMACHE. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
DROMACHE. O, be persuaded! Do not count it holy
  CASSANDRA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. It is the purpose that makes strong the vow;
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. Hold you still, I say.
  HECTOR. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. Hold you still, I say.
    Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate.
    Life every man holds dear; but the dear man
    Holds honour far more precious dear than life.
  ANDROMACHE. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
DROMACHE. Cassandra, call my father to persuade.
  ANDROMACHE. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
DROMACHE. Cassandra, call my father to persuade.
                                                       Exit CASSANDRA
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CTOR. No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth;
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
OILUS. Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you
  HECTOR. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CTOR. What vice is that, good Troilus?
  TROILUS.

10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
OILUS. Who should withhold me?
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Who should withhold me?
    Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars
    Beck'ning with fiery truncheon my retire;
    Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,
    Their eyes o'ergalled with recourse of tears;
    Nor you, my brother, with your true sword drawn,
    Oppos'd to hinder me, should stop my way,
    But by my ruin.
  CASSANDRA. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
SSANDRA. Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast;
  PRIAM.

  TROILUS.

AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS

CASSANDRA
OILUS. Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart;
  TROILUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart;
    Th' effect doth operate another way.
                                                 [Tearing the letter]
    Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together.
    My love with words and errors still she feeds,
    But edifies another with her deeds.              Exeunt severally
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go look
  THERSITES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go look
    on. That dissembling abominable varlet, Diomed, has got that same
    scurvy doting foolish young knave's sleeve of Troy there in his
    helm. I would fain see them meet, that that same young Troyan ass
    that loves the whore there might send that Greekish whoremasterly
    villain with the sleeve back to the dissembling luxurious drab of
    a sleeve-less errand. A th' t'other side, the policy of those
    crafty swearing rascals-that stale old mouse-eaten dry cheese,
    Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses -is not prov'd worth a
    blackberry. They set me up, in policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax,
    against that dog of as bad a kind, Achilles; and now is the cur,
    Ajax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm to-day;
    whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim barbarism, and policy
    grows into an ill opinion.
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx
  DIOMEDES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Thou dost miscall retire.
  THERSITES. 
12
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Hold thy whore, Grecian; now for thy whore,
    Troyan-now the sleeve, now the sleeve!
                                 Exeunt TROILUS and DIOMEDES fighting
  HECTOR. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. What art thou, Greek? Art thou for Hector's match?
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. No, no-I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave; a very
  HECTOR. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. I do believe thee. Live.                               Exit
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a plague
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a plague
    break thy neck for frighting me! What's become of the wenching
    rogues? I think they have swallowed one another. I would laugh at
    that miracle. Yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself. I'll seek
    them.                                                        Exit
  DIOMEDES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus' horse;
  SERVANT. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. I go, my lord.                                        Exit
  AGAMEMNON. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamus
  AGAMEMNON. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamus
    Hath beat down enon; bastard Margarelon
    Hath Doreus prisoner,
    And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam,
    Upon the pashed corses of the kings
    Epistrophus and Cedius. Polixenes is slain;
    Amphimacus and Thoas deadly hurt;
    Patroclus ta'en, or slain; and Palamedes
    Sore hurt and bruis'd. The dreadful Sagittary
    Appals our numbers. Haste we, Diomed,
    To reinforcement, or we perish all.
  NESTOR. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles,
  NESTOR. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles,
    And bid the snail-pac'd Ajax arm for shame.
    There is a thousand Hectors in the field;
    Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
    And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot,
    And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls
    Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
    And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
    Fall down before him like the mower's swath.
    Here, there, and everywhere, he leaves and takes;
    Dexterity so obeying appetite
    That what he will he does, and does so much
    That proof is call'd impossibility.
  ULYSSES. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. O, courage, courage, courage, Princes! Great
  ULYSSES. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. O, courage, courage, courage, Princes! Great
    Achilles Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance.
    Patroclus' wounds have rous'd his drowsy blood,
    Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
    That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to
    him, Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend
    And foams at mouth, and he is arm'd and at it,
    Roaring for Troilus; who hath done to-day
    Mad and fantastic execution,
    Engaging and redeeming of himself
    With such a careless force and forceless care
    As if that luck, in very spite of cunning,
    Bade him win all.
  AJAX. 
13
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. Troilus! thou coward Troilus!                            Exit
  DIOMEDES.

NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Where is this Hector?
    Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face;
    Know what it is to meet Achilles angry.
    Hector! where's Hector? I will none but Hector.            Exeunt
  AJAX.

  HECTOR.

CTOR. Fare thee well.
    I would have been much more a fresher man,
    Had I expected thee.
  TROILUS.

  HECTOR.

  HECTOR. 
14
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark.
    No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well;
    I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all
    But I'll be master of it. Wilt thou not, beast, abide?
    Why then, fly on; I'll hunt thee for thy hide.             Exeunt
  ACHILLES.

  ACHILLES. 
15
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PARIS
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
MENELAUS
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Come here about me, you my Myrmidons;
    Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel;
    Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath;
    And when I have the bloody Hector found,
    Empale him with your weapons round about;
    In fellest manner execute your arms.
    Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye.
    It is decreed Hector the great must die.                   Exeunt
  THERSITES.

HILLES. The dragon wing of night o'erspreads the earth
    And, stickler-like, the armies separates.
    My half-supp'd sword, that frankly would have fed,
    Pleas'd with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed.
                                                 [Sheathes his sword]
    Come, tie his body to my horse's tail;
    Along the field I will the Troyan trail.                   Exeunt
  AGAMEMNON.

CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. March patiently along. Let one be sent
    To pray Achilles see us at our tent.
    If in his death the gods have us befriended;
    Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.
    Exeunt

  TROILUS. 
15
MARGARELON
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES
HECTOR
AJAX
MENELAUS
TROILUS
ACHILLES
THERSITES
NESTOR
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. You understand me not that tell me so.
    I do not speak of flight, of fear of death,
    But dare all imminence that gods and men
    Address their dangers in. Hector is gone.
    Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
    Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd
    Go in to Troy, and say there 'Hector's dead.'
    There is a word will Priam turn to stone;
    Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
    Cold statues of the youth; and, in a word,
    Scare Troy out of itself. But, march away;
    Hector is dead; there is no more to say.
    Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,
    Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains,
    Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
    I'll through and through you. And, thou great-siz'd coward,
    No space of earth shall sunder our two hates;
    I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,
    That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy's thoughts.
    Strike a free march to Troy. With comfort go;
    Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.
  PANDARUS. 
15
MARGARELON
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PANDARUS
DIOMEDES

AJAX

TROILUS

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. But hear you, hear you!
  TROILUS.

  CRESSIDA, 
1
TROILUS
ESSIDA, daughter to Calchas
                          SCENE:
             Troy and the Greek camp before it
                  TROILUS AND CRESSIDA
                        PROLOGUE
    In Troy, there lies the scene. From isles of Greece
    The princes orgillous, their high blood chaf'd,
    Have to the port of Athens sent their ships
    Fraught with the ministers and instruments
    Of cruel war. Sixty and nine that wore
    Their crownets regal from th' Athenian bay
    Put forth toward Phrygia; and their vow is made
    To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
    The ravish'd Helen, Menelaus' queen,
    With wanton Paris sleeps-and that's the quarrel.
    To Tenedos they come,
    And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge
    Their war-like fraughtage. Now on Dardan plains
    The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch
    Their brave pavilions: Priam's six-gated city,
    Dardan, and Tymbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
    And Antenorides, with massy staples
    And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts,
    Sperr up the sons of Troy.
    Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits
    On one and other side, Troyan and Greek,
    Sets all on hazard-and hither am I come
    A Prologue arm'd, but not in confidence
    Of author's pen or actor's voice, but suited
    In like conditions as our argument,
    To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
    Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
    Beginning in the middle; starting thence away,
    To what may be digested in a play.
    Like or find fault; do as your pleasures are;
    Now good or bad, 'tis but the chance of war.
  TROILUS. 
1
TROILUS
OILUS. Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again.
  PANDARUS. 
1
TROILUS
NDARUS. Will this gear ne'er be mended?
  TROILUS. 
1
TROILUS
OILUS. The Greeks are strong, and skilful to their strength,
  PANDARUS. 
1
TROILUS
NDARUS. Well, I have told you enough of this; for my part,
  TROILUS.

  PANDARUS.

  TROILUS.

  PANDARUS.

TROILUS

  TROILUS. 
2
TROILUS
AENEAS
OILUS. Peace, you ungracious clamours! Peace, rude sounds!
    Fools on both sides! Helen must needs be fair,
    When with your blood you daily paint her thus.
    I cannot fight upon this argument;
    It is too starv'd a subject for my sword.
    But Pandarus-O gods, how do you plague me!
    I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar;
    And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo
    As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.
    Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love,
    What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we?
    Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl;
    Between our Ilium and where she resides
    Let it be call'd the wild and wand'ring flood;
    Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar
    Our doubtful hope, our convoy, and our bark.
  AENEAS. 
2
TROILUS
AENEAS
NEAS. How now, Prince Troilus! Wherefore not afield?
  TROILUS. 
2
TROILUS
AENEAS
OILUS. Because not there. This woman's answer sorts,
  AENEAS. 
2
TROILUS
AENEAS
NEAS. That Paris is returned home, and hurt.
  TROILUS.

AENEAS

  AENEAS.

AENEAS

  TROILUS.

AENEAS

TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector arm'd
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Hector was gone; but Helen was not up.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. E'en so. Hector was stirring early.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. That were we talking of, and of his anger.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Was he angry?
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. So he says here.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. True, he was so; I know the cause too; he'll lay about
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. What, is he angry too?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. O Jupiter! there's no comparison.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Then you say as I say, for I am sure he is not Hector.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. 'Tis just to each of them: he is himself.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were!
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. So he is.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Condition I had gone barefoot to India.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. He is not Hector.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Himself! no, he's not himself. Would 'a were himself!
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Excuse me.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. He is elder.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Pardon me, pardon me.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Th' other's not come to't; you shall tell me another tale
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. He shall not need it if he have his own.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Nor his qualities.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. No matter.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Nor his beauty.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. 'Twould not become him: his own's better.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. YOU have no judgment, niece. Helen herself swore th'
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. No, but brown.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. To say the truth, true and not true.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. She prais'd his complexion above Paris.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Why, Paris hath colour enough.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. So he has.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Then Troilus should have too much. If she prais'd him
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. I swear to you I think Helen loves him better than Paris.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Then she's a merry Greek indeed.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th' other day
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Indeed a tapster's arithmetic may soon bring his
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Why, he is very young, and yet will he within three pound
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Juno have mercy! How came it cloven?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Why, you know, 'tis dimpled. I think his smiling becomes
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. O, he smiles valiantly!
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Does he not?
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn!
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Why, go to, then! But to prove to you that Helen loves
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll prove it so.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Troilus! Why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Without the rack.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Alas, poor chin! Many a wart is richer.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laugh'd that
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. With millstones.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. And Cassandra laugh'd.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. But there was a more temperate fire under the pot of her
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. And Hector laugh'd.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. At what was all this laughing?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus'
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. An't had been a green hair I should have laugh'd too.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. They laugh'd not so much at the hair as at his pretty
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. What was his answer?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Quoth she 'Here's but two and fifty hairs on your chin,
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. This is her question.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. That's true; make no question of that. 'Two and fifty
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. So let it now; for it has been a great while going by.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Well, cousin, I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. So I do.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. I'll be sworn 'tis true; he will weep you, and 'twere a
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. And I'll spring up in his tears, an 'twere a nettle
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Hark! they are coming from the field. Shall we stand up
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. At your pleasure.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Here, here, here's an excellent place; here we may see
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Speak not so loud.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. That's Aeneas. Is not that a brave man? He's one of the
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Who's that?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. That's Antenor. He has a shrewd wit, I can tell you; and
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Will he give you the nod?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. You shall see.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. If he do, the rich shall have more.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. That's Hector, that, that, look you, that; there's a
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. O, a brave man!
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Is 'a not? It does a man's heart good. Look you what
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Be those with swords?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Swords! anything, he cares not; an the devil come to him,
  CRESSIDA. 
4

PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Who's that?
  PANDARUS. 
4

PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. That's Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That's
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Can Helenus fight, uncle?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Helenus! no. Yes, he'll fight indifferent well. I marvel
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. What sneaking fellow comes yonder?
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Where? yonder? That's Deiphobus. 'Tis Troilus. There's a
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Peace, for shame, peace!
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Mark him; note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon him,
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Here comes more.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Asses, fools, dolts! chaff and bran, chaff and bran!
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. There is amongst the Greeks Achilles, a better man than
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Achilles? A drayman, a porter, a very camel!
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Well, well.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Well, well! Why, have you any discretion? Have you any
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Ay, a minc'd man; and then to be bak'd with no date in
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. You are such a woman! A man knows not at what ward you
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Upon my back, to defend my belly; upon my wit, to defend
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Say one of your watches.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Nay, I'll watch you for that; and that's one of the
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. You are such another!
  BOY. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
Y. Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Where?
  BOY. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
Y. At your own house; there he unarms him.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Good boy, tell him I come.                       Exit Boy
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. Adieu, uncle.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. I will be with you, niece, by and by.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. To bring, uncle.
  PANDARUS. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
NDARUS. Ay, a token from Troilus.
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
PANDARUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. By the same token, you are a bawd.
  CRESSIDA. 
3
TROILUS
AENEAS
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. By the same token, you are a bawd.
                                                        Exit PANDARUS
  CRESSIDA. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
ESSIDA. By the same token, you are a bawd.
                                                        Exit PANDARUS
    Words, vows, gifts, tears, and love's full sacrifice,
    He offers in another's enterprise;
    But more in Troilus thousand-fold I see
    Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be,
    Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing:
    Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing.
    That she belov'd knows nought that knows not this:
    Men prize the thing ungain'd more than it is.
    That she was never yet that ever knew
    Love got so sweet as when desire did sue;
    Therefore this maxim out of love I teach:
    Achievement is command; ungain'd, beseech.
    Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear,
    Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.                 Exit
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Princes,
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. With due observance of thy godlike seat,
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. Agamemnon,
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Speak, Prince of Ithaca; and be't of less expect
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down,
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses,
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. And in the imitation of these twain-
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. They tax our policy and call it cowardice,
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. What trumpet? Look, Menelaus.
  MENELAUS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NELAUS. From Troy.
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. What would you fore our tent?
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Is this great Agamemnon's tent, I pray you?
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Even this.
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. May one that is a herald and a prince
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. With surety stronger than Achilles' an
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Fair leave and large security. How may
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. How?
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Ay;
  AGAMEMNON. 
4

AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA

  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd,
  AGAMEMNON.

AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself Aeneas?
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Ay, Greek, that is my name.
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. What's your affair, I pray you?
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Sir, pardon; 'tis for Agamemnon's ears.
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. He hears nought privately that comes from Troy.
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Nor I from Troy come not to whisper with him;
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Speak frankly as the wind;
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Trumpet, blow loud,
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. This shall be told our lovers, Lord Aeneas.
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
  AENEAS. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
NEAS. Now heavens forfend such scarcity of youth!
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. Amen.
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Fair Lord Aeneas, let me touch your hand;
  AGAMEMNON. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AMEMNON. Fair Lord Aeneas, let me touch your hand;
    To our pavilion shall I lead you, first.
    Achilles shall have word of this intent;
    So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent.
    Yourself shall feast with us before you go,
    And find the welcome of a noble foe.
                                    Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. Nestor!
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. What says Ulysses?
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. I have a young conception in my brain;
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. What is't?
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. This 'tis:
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Well, and how?
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. True. The purpose is perspicuous even as substance
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. And wake him to the answer, think you?
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Why, 'tis most meet. Who may you else oppose
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. Give pardon to my speech.
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. I see them not with my old eyes. What are they?
  ULYSSES. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
YSSES. What glory our Achilles shares from Hector,
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Now, Ulysses, I begin to relish thy advice;
  NESTOR. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
STOR. Now, Ulysses, I begin to relish thy advice;
    And I will give a taste thereof forthwith
    To Agamemnon. Go we to him straight.
    Two curs shall tame each other: pride alone
    Must tarre the mastiffs on, as 'twere their bone.          Exeunt
  AJAX. 
4
TROILUS
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
CRESSIDA
AX. Thersites!
  THERSITES.

CRESSIDA

  AJAX.

CRESSIDA

  AJAX.

  AJAX.

  THERSITES.

8
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
CTOR. I am yours,
    You valiant offspring of great Priamus.
    I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
    The dull and factious nobles of the Greeks
    Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits.
    I was advertis'd their great general slept,
    Whilst emulation in the army crept.
    This, I presume, will wake him.                            Exeunt
  THERSITES. 
8
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. How now, Thersites! What, lost in the labyrinth of thy
  THERSITES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. How now, Thersites! What, lost in the labyrinth of thy
    fury? Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I
    rail at him. O worthy satisfaction! Would it were otherwise: that
    I could beat him, whilst he rail'd at me! 'Sfoot, I'll learn to
    conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of my spiteful
    execrations. Then there's Achilles, a rare engineer! If Troy be
    not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till
    they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus,
    forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods, and, Mercury, lose
    all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that
    little little less-than-little wit from them that they have!
    which short-arm'd ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce,
    it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider without
    drawing their massy irons and cutting the web. After this, the
    vengeance on the whole camp! or, rather, the Neapolitan
    bone-ache! for that, methinks, is the curse depending on those
    that war for a placket. I have said my prayers; and devil Envy
    say 'Amen.' What ho! my Lord Achilles!
  PATROCLUS. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and
  THERSITES.

AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM

THERSITES

CASSANDRA

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Make that demand of the Creator. It suffices me thou
  ACHILLES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Come, Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody. Come in with me,
  THERSITES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery.
  THERSITES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery.
    All the argument is a whore and a cuckold-a good quarrel to draw
    emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now the dry serpigo on
    the subject, and war and lechery confound all!               Exit
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Where is Achilles?
  PATROCLUS. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. Within his tent; but ill-dispos'd, my lord.
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Let it be known to him that we are here.
  PATROCLUS. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. I shall say so to him.                              Exit
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. We saw him at the opening of his tent.
  AJAX. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart. You may call it
  NESTOR. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. He.
  NESTOR. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. No; you see he is his argument that has his argument-
  NESTOR. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. All the better; their fraction is more our wish than their
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie.
  NESTOR. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. No Achilles with him.
  ULYSSES. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy; his legs
  PATROCLUS. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. Achilles bids me say he is much sorry
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Hear you, Patroclus.
  PATROCLUS. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. I shall, and bring his answer presently.            Exit
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. In second voice we'll not be satisfied;
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. In second voice we'll not be satisfied;
    We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.
                                                         Exit ULYSSES
  AJAX. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. What is he more than another?
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. No more than what he thinks he is.
  AJAX. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. No question.
  AJAX. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. Will you subscribe his thought and say he is?
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as wise,
  AJAX. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not
  AGAMEMNON. 
9
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the
  AGAMEMNON. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the
    fairer. He that is proud eats up himself. Pride is his own glass,
    his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself
    but in the deed devours the deed in the praise.
  AJAX. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. I do hate a proud man as I do hate the engend'ring of toads.
  NESTOR. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. [Aside] And yet he loves himself: is't not strange?
  ULYSSES. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.
  AGAMEMNON. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. What's his excuse?
  ULYSSES.

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. He doth rely on none;

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Why will he not, upon our fair request,
  ULYSSES.

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Things small as nothing, for request's sake only,

ULYSSES

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Let Ajax go to him.

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. O Agamemnon, let it not be so!

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. [Aside] O, this is well! He rubs the vein of him.
  DIOMEDES. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. [Aside] And how his silence drinks up this applause!
  AJAX. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the
  AGAMEMNON. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. O, no, you shall not go.
  AJAX. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. An 'a be proud with me I'll pheeze his pride.
  ULYSSES. 
10
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
YSSES. Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.
  AJAX. 
10

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. A paltry, insolent fellow!
  NESTOR.

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. [Aside] How he describes himself!
  AJAX.

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

CASSANDRA

TROILUS

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AX. I will knead him, I'll make him supple.

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
STOR. Our noble general, do not do so.
  DIOMEDES.

PRIAM

TROILUS

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM

TROILUS

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

CASSANDRA

TROILUS

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  AGAMEMNON.

THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
AMEMNON. Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep.
    Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.
    Exeunt
  PANDARUS. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Friend, you-pray you, a word. Do you not follow the young
  SERVANT. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. Ay, sir, when he goes before me.
  PANDARUS. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. You depend upon him, I mean?
  SERVANT. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. Sir, I do depend upon the lord.
  PANDARUS. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. You depend upon a notable gentleman; I must needs praise
  SERVANT. 
11

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  PANDARUS.

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  SERVANT.

PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS

CRESSIDA

ULYSSES

PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. I do desire it.

11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. You are in the state of grace.
  PANDARUS. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Grace! Not so, friend; honour and lordship are my titles.
  SERVANT. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. I do but partly know, sir; it is music in parts.
  PANDARUS. 
11
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Know you the musicians?
  SERVANT.

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. Wholly, sir.

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Who play they to?
  SERVANT.

AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES

CASSANDRA
NDARUS. At whose pleasure, friend?
  SERVANT.

AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RVANT. At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.
  PANDARUS.

  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.
    Th' imaginary relish is so sweet
    That it enchants my sense; what will it be
    When that the wat'ry palate tastes indeed
    Love's thrice-repured nectar? Death, I fear me;
    Swooning destruction; or some joy too fine,
    Too subtle-potent, tun'd too sharp in sweetness,
    For the capacity of my ruder powers.
    I fear it much; and I do fear besides
    That I shall lose distinction in my joys;
    As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps
    The enemy flying.
  PANDARUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. She's making her ready, she'll come straight; you must be
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom.
  TROILUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom.
    My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse,
    And all my powers do their bestowing lose,
    Like vassalage at unawares encount'ring
    The eye of majesty.
  PANDARUS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON

  CRESSIDA.

CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safer footing

PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES

CASSANDRA
OILUS. O, let my lady apprehend no fear! In all Cupid's pageant
  CRESSIDA.

12
AENEAS

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber
    and a bed; which bed, because it shall not speak of your
    pretty encounters, press it to death. Away!
    And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here,
    Bed, chamber, pander, to provide this gear!                Exeunt
  CALCHAS. 
12
AENEAS
AGAMEMNON
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  AGAMEMNON.

  ACHILLES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus.
  ACHILLES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus.
    I'll send the fool to Ajax, and desire him
    T' invite the Troyan lords, after the combat,
    To see us here unarm'd. I have a woman's longing,
    An appetite that I am sick withal,
    To see great Hector in his weeds of peace;
    To talk with him, and to behold his visage,
    Even to my full of view.
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. A wonder!
  ACHILLES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. What?
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Ajax goes up and down the field asking for himself.
  ACHILLES. 
11

ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES

CASSANDRA

  THERSITES.

  ACHILLES.

CASSANDRA

  THERSITES.

TROILUS
THERSITES

CASSANDRA

  ACHILLES.

  ACHILLES.

TROILUS

CASSANDRA

  PATROCLUS.

PRIAM

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

  THERSITES. 
11

PATROCLUS
PARIS

  PATROCLUS. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
TROCLUS. I come from the worthy Achilles-
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

TROILUS
THERSITES

CASSANDRA

  PATROCLUS.

  THERSITES.

  THERSITES.

PARIS

  PATROCLUS.

PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?
  THERSITES. 
11

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. No, but he's out a tune thus. What music will be in him
  ACHILLES. 
11
AENEAS

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.
  THERSITES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Let me carry another to his horse; for that's the more
  ACHILLES. 
11
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
ACHILLES
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd;
  ACHILLES. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
HILLES. My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd;
    And I myself see not the bottom of it.
                                        Exeunt ACHILLES and PATROCLUS
  THERSITES. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ERSITES. Would the fountain of your mind were clear again, that I
  PARIS. 
10

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. See, ho! Who is that there?
  DEIPHOBUS. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
IPHOBUS. It is the Lord Aeneas.
  AENEAS.

PARIS
PANDARUS

THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. Is the Prince there in person?
  DIOMEDES. 
10

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. That's my mind too. Good morrow, Lord Aeneas.
  PARIS. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. A valiant Greek, Aeneas -take his hand:
  AENEAS.

CASSANDRA

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. And thou shalt hunt a lion, that will fly
  DIOMEDES.

PARIS

PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. We sympathise. Jove let Aeneas live,
  AENEAS. 
10

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. We know each other well.

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. This is the most despiteful'st gentle greeting
  AENEAS. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. I was sent for to the King; but why, I know not.
  PARIS. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS

PRIAM

THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek
  AENEAS.

CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

CASSANDRA
RIS. There is no help;

PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. You are too bitter to your country-woman.
  DIOMEDES. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OMEDES. She's bitter to her country. Hear me, Paris:
  PARIS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
  PARIS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
RIS. Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
    Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy;
    But we in silence hold this virtue well:
    We'll not commend what we intend to sell.
    Here lies our way.                                         Exeunt
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Dear, trouble not yourself; the morn is cold.
  CRESSIDA. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down;
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS

TROILUS
THERSITES

PARIS

CRESSIDA

CASSANDRA

PATROCLUS
PARIS

PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays
  CRESSIDA. 
10

PATROCLUS
PARIS

THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA

PATROCLUS
PARIS

PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. [Within] What's all the doors open here?
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. It is your uncle.
  CRESSIDA. 
10

ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. A pestilence on him! Now will he be mocking.
  PANDARUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. How now, how now! How go maidenheads?
  CRESSIDA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle.
  PANDARUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. To do what? to do what? Let her say what.
  CRESSIDA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Come, come, beshrew your heart! You'll ne'er be good,
  PANDARUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Ha, ha! Alas, poor wretch! a poor capocchia! hast not
  CRESSIDA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Did not I tell you? Would he were knock'd i' th' head!
  TROILUS. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
OILUS. Ha! ha!
  CRESSIDA. 
10
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
TROILUS
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Come, you are deceiv'd, I think of no such thing.
  CRESSIDA. 
9
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
ESSIDA. Come, you are deceiv'd, I think of no such thing.
    How earnestly they knock! Pray you come in:
    I would not for half Troy have you seen here.
                                          Exeunt TROILUS and CRESSIDA
  PANDARUS. 
9
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Who's there? What's the matter? Will you beat down the
  PANDARUS. 
9
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NDARUS. Who's there? What's the matter? Will you beat down the
    door? How now? What's the matter?
  AENEAS. 
9
AENEAS
ULYSSES
PATROCLUS
PARIS
PANDARUS
PRIAM
THERSITES
CRESSIDA
CASSANDRA
NEAS. Good morrow, lord, good morrow.
  PANDARUS. 
9
